elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as promising light-harvesting platforms for energy-transfer materials. However, the targeted construction of MOFs with desirable photophysical properties and pore structures is still a challenge. Herein, 1,1,2,2-tetrakis­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­ethene (tppe) is selected as the ligand for the construction of light-harvesting MOFs due to its highly emissive and rigid backbone, which could benefit the light-harvesting performance of the MOFs. Three MOFs (MOFs 1–3) were obtained on the basis of different metal centers (Zn2+ and Cd2+) and carboxylate building blocks. The complete structure characterization of the MOFs helps the illustration of the principles for structure tuning of this system. All three MOFs exhibit strong tppe-originated photoluminescence emission, with quantum yields as high as 47.6%. The fluorescence quantum yield and time-resolved fluorescence studies reveal that a remarkable energy-transfer efficiency (up to 96%) was achieved in this system. These results clearly indicate tppe-MOFs could be promising light-harvesting materials.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as promising light-harvesting platforms for energy-transfer materials. However, the targeted construction of MOFs with desirable photophysical properties and pore structures is still a challenge. Herein, 1,1,2,2-tetrakis(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)ethene (tppe) is selected as the ligand for the construction of light-harvesting MOFs due to its highly emissive and rigid backbone, which could benefit the light-harvesting performance of the MOFs. Three MOFs (MOFs 1-3) were obtained on the basis of different metal centers (Zn2+ and Cd2+) and carboxylate building blocks. The complete structure characterization of the MOFs helps the illustration of the principles for structure tuning of this system. All three MOFs exhibit strong tppe-originated photoluminescence emission, with quantum yields as high as 47.6%. The fluorescence quantum yield and time-resolved fluorescence studies reveal that a remarkable energy-transfer efficiency (up to 96%) was achieved in this system. These results clearly indicate tppe-MOFs could be promising light-harvesting materials.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are an emerging class of porous materials with tailorable structures, readily modulated functions, and wide potential applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, light emitting, sensing, ion exchange, and drug delivery. Among the various potential applications of MOFs, solid-state light harvesting is quite promising for taking advantage of their attractive photophysical properties on the basis of their component and structural features. Recently, a range of light-harvesting MOF systems based on distinct construction strategies have been reported and their diverse properties well imply the potential of MOFs in this field. For instance, Lin, Meyer, and co-workers reported the fabrication of Ru­(II)/Os­(II) (2,2′-bipyridine)3-derived MOFs-based devices showing intracrystal site-to-site energy migration dynamics through the luminescence quenching mechanism. Farha and co-workers demonstrated a series of porphyrin-based MOFs featuring exciton propagation capabilities as the light-harvesting platform for energy-transfer investigations.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are an emerging class of porous materials with tailorable structures, readily modulated functions, and wide potential applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, light emitting, sensing, ion exchange, and drug delivery. Among the various potential applications of MOFs, solid-state light harvesting is quite promising for taking advantage of their attractive photophysical properties on the basis of their component and structural features. Recently, a range of light-harvesting MOF systems based on distinct construction strategies have been reported and their diverse properties well imply the potential of MOFs in this field. For instance, Lin, Meyer, and co-workers reported the fabrication of Ru(II)/Os(II) (2,2'-bipyridine)3-derived MOFs-based devices showing intracrystal site-to-site energy migration dynamics through the luminescence quenching mechanism. Farha and co-workers demonstrated a series of porphyrin-based MOFs featuring exciton propagation capabilities as the light-harvesting platform for energy-transfer investigations.

elements.content: From the examples mentioned above, it could be concluded that the light-harvesting behavior of MOFs is mainly attributed to the antenna effect of the framework, which is mainly originated from the absorption character of organic ligands. On the other hand, the overlaps between the emission of the donor framework and the absorption of the acceptor species together with the proper distance-dependent interaction among them greatly affect the energy-transfer performance. Therefore, the main challenge in this field lies in the construction of MOFs with both suitable photophysical properties and pore structures, which could facilitate the performance of the materials in the perspectives mentioned above.
elements.clean_text: From the examples mentioned above, it could be concluded that the light-harvesting behavior of MOFs is mainly attributed to the antenna effect of the framework, which is mainly originated from the absorption character of organic ligands. On the other hand, the overlaps between the emission of the donor framework and the absorption of the acceptor species together with the proper distance-dependent interaction among them greatly affect the energy-transfer performance. Therefore, the main challenge in this field lies in the construction of MOFs with both suitable photophysical properties and pore structures, which could facilitate the performance of the materials in the perspectives mentioned above.

elements.content: On the basis of our previous experiences in luminescent MOFs and porous polymers featuring light-harvesting properties, tetraphenylethene (TPE), as one of the most accessible and simplest aggregation-induced emission (AIE) chromophores,has attracted our attention. As reported, the aggregation-induced emission of TPE could result in a broad emission band with high intensity and its rigid planar backbone could benefit the access of acceptor species for the energy-transfer process. Their unique luminescence behavior has been harnessed for the synthesis of TPE-based luminescent MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, the use of TPE-based MOFs for light-harvesting and energy-transfer applications is still in a nascent yet promising stage.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of our previous experiences in luminescent MOFs and porous polymers featuring light-harvesting properties, tetraphenylethene (TPE), as one of the most accessible and simplest aggregation-induced emission (AIE) chromophores,has attracted our attention. As reported, the aggregation-induced emission of TPE could result in a broad emission band with high intensity and its rigid planar backbone could benefit the access of acceptor species for the energy-transfer process. Their unique luminescence behavior has been harnessed for the synthesis of TPE-based luminescent MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, the use of TPE-based MOFs for light-harvesting and energy-transfer applications is still in a nascent yet promising stage.

elements.content: On the basis of the considerations mentioned above, we have made much effort in this field. By utilizing 1,1,2,2-tetrakis­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­ethene (tppe), a typical TPE-based ligand that exhibits high fluorescent quantum yield, as the building block of MOFs, an unprecedented donor–acceptor system could be achieved with the energy-accepting counterparts in the confined pore structure (). Herein, we reported the targeted construction of light-harvesting MOFs based on tppe ligand. Through the coordination assembly of tppe with Zn2+/Cd2+ ions and different carboxylate building blocks, three MOFs featuring distinct porous frameworks were obtained, namely [Zn3(tppe)1.5(mdc)3]·10DMF (MOF-1), [Cd4(tppe)2(1,4-ndc)4]·8DMF (MOF-2), and [Cd2(tppe)­(2,6-ndc)2]·12DMF (MOF-3), (m-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2mdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2ndc), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc), and N′,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)) (). The resulting MOFs revealed broad tppe-based emissions (ca. 425 to 650 nm) and relatively high fluorescence quantum yield (max Φfl = 47.6%), which makes them promising candidates for light-harvesting. Furthermore, the host–guest energy-transfer properties of MOF-3, which presented the highest porosity and quantum yield among the three MOFs, were investigated in detail with rhodamine 6G (Rho6G) as the acceptor and a remarkable energy-transfer efficiency (up to 96%) was achieved. All of these results suggest that the tppe-based MOFs could be promising light-harvesting materials.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the considerations mentioned above, we have made much effort in this field. By utilizing 1,1,2,2-tetrakis(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)ethene (tppe), a typical TPE-based ligand that exhibits high fluorescent quantum yield, as the building block of MOFs, an unprecedented donor-acceptor system could be achieved with the energy-accepting counterparts in the confined pore structure (). Herein, we reported the targeted construction of light-harvesting MOFs based on tppe ligand. Through the coordination assembly of tppe with Zn2+/Cd2+ ions and different carboxylate building blocks, three MOFs featuring distinct porous frameworks were obtained, namely [Zn3(tppe)1.5(mdc)3]⋅10DMF (MOF-1), [Cd4(tppe)2(1,4-ndc)4]⋅8DMF (MOF-2), and [Cd2(tppe)(2,6-ndc)2]⋅12DMF (MOF-3), (m-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2mdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2ndc), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc), and N',N-dimethylformamide (DMF)) (). The resulting MOFs revealed broad tppe-based emissions (ca. 425 to 650 nm) and relatively high fluorescence quantum yield (max Φfl = 47.6%), which makes them promising candidates for light-harvesting. Furthermore, the host-guest energy-transfer properties of MOF-3, which presented the highest porosity and quantum yield among the three MOFs, were investigated in detail with rhodamine 6G (Rho6G) as the acceptor and a remarkable energy-transfer efficiency (up to 96%) was achieved. All of these results suggest that the tppe-based MOFs could be promising light-harvesting materials.

elements.clean_text: 2  Construction of MOFs 1-3 (Purple and Green Polyhedrons Represent Zn2+ and Cd2+, Respectively)

elements.content: For the construction of tppe-based MOFs as donor framework to realize guest acceptor-based light-harvesting functions, the porous character of the framework is one of the critical factors that should be considered because the pore dimension and the pore surface chemistry determine the accessible guest species and the loading capacity. On the basis of our previous investigations of [Cd2(tppe)­(bpdc)2(H2O)]·solvent based on 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc), we have realized that the introduction of carboxylate acids as auxiliary ligand could be an effective way for the assembly of tppe-based MOFs. However, the accessible pore volume of the resulting MOF could be reduced due to the interpenetration of the networks originated from the elongated auxiliary ligand. Therefore, structure modulation was performed with different carboxylic acids and metal ions for the exploration of suitable host framework and the MOFs 1–3 were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Construction, Crystal Structures, and Characterization of MOFs 1-3 

For the construction of tppe-based MOFs as donor framework to realize guest acceptor-based light-harvesting functions, the porous character of the framework is one of the critical factors that should be considered because the pore dimension and the pore surface chemistry determine the accessible guest species and the loading capacity. On the basis of our previous investigations of [Cd2(tppe)(bpdc)2(H2O)]⋅solvent based on 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc), we have realized that the introduction of carboxylate acids as auxiliary ligand could be an effective way for the assembly of tppe-based MOFs. However, the accessible pore volume of the resulting MOF could be reduced due to the interpenetration of the networks originated from the elongated auxiliary ligand. Therefore, structure modulation was performed with different carboxylic acids and metal ions for the exploration of suitable host framework and the MOFs 1-3 were obtained.

elements.content: The MOF-1 crystallizes in space group P6422. The asymmetric unit of MOF-1 contains one independent Zn2+ ion, one quarter tppe ligand, and half mdc2– ligand (Figure S2). Zn1 reveals distorted octahedral coordination geometry defined by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct mdc2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two tppe ligands. Each tppe ligand links four Zn2+ ions (Figure S3a) and is further extended to one-dimensional (1D) bands. The bands are interconnected by mdc2– ligands at Zn2+ ions sites (Figure S3b) to generate a three-dimensional (3D) network ( and S3c) showing a 4,4-connected self-interpenetrated topology with the Schläfli symbol {4·105}2{42·104} (Figure S4). There are 1D channels with about 1.0 nm diameter (taking the van der Waals radii into account) along the a-axis of the framework (), which are occupied by solvent molecules. SQUEEZE calculations indicate that the vacant space in MOF-1 is about 51.3% of the cell volume (3263.5 Å3 of the 6314.0 Å3 unit cell volume).
elements.clean_text: The MOF-1 crystallizes in space group P6422. The asymmetric unit of MOF-1 contains one independent Zn2+ ion, one quarter tppe ligand, and half mdc2- ligand (Figure S2). Zn1 reveals distorted octahedral coordination geometry defined by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two distinct mdc2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two tppe ligands. Each tppe ligand links four Zn2+ ions (Figure S3a) and is further extended to one-dimensional (1D) bands. The bands are interconnected by mdc2- ligands at Zn2+ ions sites (Figure S3b) to generate a three-dimensional (3D) network ( and S3c) showing a 4,4-connected self-interpenetrated topology with the Schläfli symbol {4⋅105}2{42⋅104} (Figure S4). There are 1D channels with about 1.0 nm diameter (taking the van der Waals radii into account) along the a-axis of the framework (), which are occupied by solvent molecules. SQUEEZE calculations indicate that the vacant space in MOF-1 is about 51.3% of the cell volume (3263.5 Å3 of the 6314.0 Å3 unit cell volume).

elements.content: Framework structure of MOF-1. The different colors (purple and green) indicate the two distinct self-interpenetrated networks that form the complete structure of MOF-1.
elements.clean_text: 1  Framework structure of MOF-1. The different colors (purple and green) indicate the two distinct self-interpenetrated networks that form the complete structure of MOF-1.

elements.content: The MOF-2 crystallizes in space group Cc. The asymmetric unit contains four Cd2+ ions, two tppe ligands, and four 1,4-ndc2– ligands (Figure S5a). The carboxylate groups of the 1,4-ndc2– ligands reveal two different coordination modes to bridge one pair of Cd2+ ions to give a binuclear clusters for Cd1 and Cd2 with chelating and bridging modes (Figure S5c), whereas for Cd3 and Cd4 with bidentate mode (Figure S5b). Both types of the binuclear clusters are bridged by the 1,4-ndc2– ligands to generate a two-dimensional (2D) rhombic layer along the ab plane (Figure S6). Furthermore, the adjacent layers are pillared by the tppe ligands to form a 3D “pillar-layer” porous framework with 1D channels ( and S7). After removal of solvent molecules filled in the pore space, the accessible volume is 51.1% (9892.8 Å3 of the 19342.0 Å3 unit cell volume), as estimated using the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON.
elements.clean_text: The MOF-2 crystallizes in space group Cc. The asymmetric unit contains four Cd2+ ions, two tppe ligands, and four 1,4-ndc2- ligands (Figure S5a). The carboxylate groups of the 1,4-ndc2- ligands reveal two different coordination modes to bridge one pair of Cd2+ ions to give a binuclear clusters for Cd1 and Cd2 with chelating and bridging modes (Figure S5c), whereas for Cd3 and Cd4 with bidentate mode (Figure S5b). Both types of the binuclear clusters are bridged by the 1,4-ndc2- ligands to generate a two-dimensional (2D) rhombic layer along the ab plane (Figure S6). Furthermore, the adjacent layers are pillared by the tppe ligands to form a 3D "pillar-layer" porous framework with 1D channels ( and S7). After removal of solvent molecules filled in the pore space, the accessible volume is 51.1% (9892.8 Å3 of the 19342.0 Å3 unit cell volume), as estimated using the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON.

elements.content: Pillar-layer framework structure of MOF-2.
elements.clean_text: 2  Pillar-layer framework structure of MOF-2.

elements.content: The MOF-3 crystallizes in space group P2/n, whereas it has a similar pillar-layer structure as that of MOF-2. Its asymmetric unit consists of two Cd2+ ions, two tppe ligands, and four 2,6-ndc2– ligands. Both of the classes of the Cd2+ ions (Cd1 and Cd2) are hexacoordinated to generate an octahedral coordination geometry (Figure S9). Every two Cd2+ ions of the same class are bonded through the carboxylates from 2,6-ndc2– ligands to give binuclear units, which are further interconnected by 2,6-ndc2– ligands to give a 2D rhomboid layer showing ABAB stacking fashions, depending on the class of metal ions (a). The 2D layers are further pillared by tppe ligands to be extended into the 3D framework with rhombic 1D channels along the a-axis (∼18.9 × 22.2 Å2, measured between opposite atoms, excluding the van der Waals radius of the corresponding atoms) (b and S10). Compared to that of MOF-2, the accessible volume in MOF-3 increases to 63.5% (7782.4 Å3 of the 12260.9 Å3 unit cell volume), which should be attributed to the presence of the longer 2,6-ndc2+ ligand that benefits the extension of the layers.
elements.clean_text: The MOF-3 crystallizes in space group P2/n, whereas it has a similar pillar-layer structure as that of MOF-2. Its asymmetric unit consists of two Cd2+ ions, two tppe ligands, and four 2,6-ndc2- ligands. Both of the classes of the Cd2+ ions (Cd1 and Cd2) are hexacoordinated to generate an octahedral coordination geometry (Figure S9). Every two Cd2+ ions of the same class are bonded through the carboxylates from 2,6-ndc2- ligands to give binuclear units, which are further interconnected by 2,6-ndc2- ligands to give a 2D rhomboid layer showing ABAB stacking fashions, depending on the class of metal ions (a). The 2D layers are further pillared by tppe ligands to be extended into the 3D framework with rhombic 1D channels along the a-axis (~18.9 × 22.2 Å2, measured between opposite atoms, excluding the van der Waals radius of the corresponding atoms) (b and S10). Compared to that of MOF-2, the accessible volume in MOF-3 increases to 63.5% (7782.4 Å3 of the 12260.9 Å3 unit cell volume), which should be attributed to the presence of the longer 2,6-ndc2+ ligand that benefits the extension of the layers.

elements.content: Framework structure of MOF-3. (a) Two-dimensional metal–carboxylate layers in ABAB fashions (distinct in purple and green, respectively); (b) the 3D pillar-layer structure viewed along a-axis.
elements.clean_text: 3  Framework structure of MOF-3. (a) Two-dimensional metal-carboxylate layers in ABAB fashions (distinct in purple and green, respectively); (b) the 3D pillar-layer structure viewed along a-axis.

elements.content: By comparing the structures of MOFs 1–3 with that of [Cd2(tppe)­(bpdc)2(H2O)]·solvent, it is noteworthy that no interpenetration of networks is observed in MOFs 1–3, which might be attributed to the limited length of the auxiliary carboxylate ligands. Therefore, all of the three MOFs reveal considerable porosity and proper pore dimensions, which promise their loading of energy-accepting guest. On the other hand, among the three MOFs reported herein, MOF-2 and MOF-3 reveal obvious similarity in pillar-layer structures. Considering their similar synthesis conditions and the auxiliary carboxylate ligands used, this result suggests that systematic structure modulation might be achieved on the basis of this system with different auxiliary carboxylate ligands, which will also be valuable for further property modulations.
elements.clean_text: By comparing the structures of MOFs 1-3 with that of [Cd2(tppe)(bpdc)2(H2O)]⋅solvent, it is noteworthy that no interpenetration of networks is observed in MOFs 1-3, which might be attributed to the limited length of the auxiliary carboxylate ligands. Therefore, all of the three MOFs reveal considerable porosity and proper pore dimensions, which promise their loading of energy-accepting guest. On the other hand, among the three MOFs reported herein, MOF-2 and MOF-3 reveal obvious similarity in pillar-layer structures. Considering their similar synthesis conditions and the auxiliary carboxylate ligands used, this result suggests that systematic structure modulation might be achieved on the basis of this system with different auxiliary carboxylate ligands, which will also be valuable for further property modulations.

elements.content: In addition to the crystal structure characterization, the phase purity of the bulk sample and stability of the MOFs were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), respectively. The PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized samples closely match those simulated from single-crystal structures, indicating the high phase purity of the bulk samples (Figure S11). On the other hand, the TGA profiles of the as-synthesized samples (Figure S12) display two continuous weight losses of 31.3% (calcd 30.7%) from 25 to 182 °C for MOF-1, three continuous weight losses of 17.8% (calcd 18.3%) from 77 to 310 °C for MOF-2, and 40.4% (calcd 38.9%) weight losses from 25 to 222 °C for MOF-3. All of these weight losses correspond to the evaporation of DMF molecules within the frameworks upon heating. Further increasing the temperature induced the collapse of these frameworks at 327, 307, and 340 °C, respectively. All of these results suggest the remarkable stability of these MOFs, which could be promising for the further investigation of their emission properties.
elements.clean_text: In addition to the crystal structure characterization, the phase purity of the bulk sample and stability of the MOFs were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), respectively. The PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized samples closely match those simulated from single-crystal structures, indicating the high phase purity of the bulk samples (Figure S11). On the other hand, the TGA profiles of the as-synthesized samples (Figure S12) display two continuous weight losses of 31.3% (calcd 30.7%) from 25 to 182 °C for MOF-1, three continuous weight losses of 17.8% (calcd 18.3%) from 77 to 310 °C for MOF-2, and 40.4% (calcd 38.9%) weight losses from 25 to 222 °C for MOF-3. All of these weight losses correspond to the evaporation of DMF molecules within the frameworks upon heating. Further increasing the temperature induced the collapse of these frameworks at 327, 307, and 340 °C, respectively. All of these results suggest the remarkable stability of these MOFs, which could be promising for the further investigation of their emission properties.

elements.content: The porosity of MOFs 1–3 was analyzed by N2 adsorption isotherms obtained at 77 K. Prior to adsorption analysis, the crystals were activated at 130 °C under vacuum to remove the guest molecules in channels. As shown in , the isotherms of MOF-3 exhibit type I characteristics, which indicates the microporous nature of MOF-3. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller and Langmuir surface areas of MOF-3 were calculated to be 560 and 692 m2 g–1, respectively. In contrast, MOF-1 and MOF-2 exhibit no obvious N2 uptake. This phenomenon indicates MOF-3 is a much better candidate for loading guest molecule for energy-transfer and light-harvesting applications.
elements.clean_text:
Porosity Characterization of MOFs 1-3 

The porosity of MOFs 1-3 was analyzed by N2 adsorption isotherms obtained at 77 K. Prior to adsorption analysis, the crystals were activated at 130 °C under vacuum to remove the guest molecules in channels. As shown in , the isotherms of MOF-3 exhibit type I characteristics, which indicates the microporous nature of MOF-3. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and Langmuir surface areas of MOF-3 were calculated to be 560 and 692 m2 g-1, respectively. In contrast, MOF-1 and MOF-2 exhibit no obvious N2 uptake. This phenomenon indicates MOF-3 is a much better candidate for loading guest molecule for energy-transfer and light-harvesting applications.

elements.content: N2 sorption isotherms of MOFs 1–3.
elements.clean_text: 4  N2 sorption isotherms of MOFs 1-3.

elements.content: To evaluate the potential of MOFs 1–3 as a light-harvesting host, their luminescent properties were assessed at room temperature in a solid state (Figure S14). As reported before, the free tppe ligand exhibits an intense and broad band with a maximum at 505 nm upon excitation at 370 nm, which is attributed to the π–π* electron transition (Figure S14a). Compared with that, the MOFs 1–3 exhibit excitation spectra similar to that of tppe in solid state (Figure S14b–d), which involves a ligand-centered excited state. Accordingly, the emission maxima for MOFs 1–3 (493–515 nm) are also found to be originated from that of tppe ligand (Figure S15). The slight differences in the emission spectra of the MOFs from that of the tppe ligand should be attributed to the change of ligand configuration in response to the coordination. On the other hand, the emission bands of the MOFs cover a wide range from ca. 425 to 650 nm. Because the effective energy transfer between donor and acceptor requires the overlap between the emission of the donor and the excitation of the acceptor, the wide emission bands of the MOFs promise their high potential for acceptors with various excitations.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties of MOFs 1-3 

To evaluate the potential of MOFs 1-3 as a light-harvesting host, their luminescent properties were assessed at room temperature in a solid state (Figure S14). As reported before, the free tppe ligand exhibits an intense and broad band with a maximum at 505 nm upon excitation at 370 nm, which is attributed to the π-π* electron transition (Figure S14a). Compared with that, the MOFs 1-3 exhibit excitation spectra similar to that of tppe in solid state (Figure S14b-d), which involves a ligand-centered excited state. Accordingly, the emission maxima for MOFs 1-3 (493-515 nm) are also found to be originated from that of tppe ligand (Figure S15). The slight differences in the emission spectra of the MOFs from that of the tppe ligand should be attributed to the change of ligand configuration in response to the coordination. On the other hand, the emission bands of the MOFs cover a wide range from ca. 425 to 650 nm. Because the effective energy transfer between donor and acceptor requires the overlap between the emission of the donor and the excitation of the acceptor, the wide emission bands of the MOFs promise their high potential for acceptors with various excitations.

elements.content: Furthermore, as another critical factor that determines the efficiency of light-harvesting and energy-transfer systems, the absolute fluorescence quantum yield (Φfl) of the MOFs were also investigated. The Φfl of the MOFs 1–3 is determined to be 37.1, 41.7, and 47.6%, respectively, which is slightly lower than that of the tppe ligand (57.2%). The intense solid-state emission of MOFs 1–3 should be attributed to the AIE effect originated from of the rigidification of tppe ligand in the frameworks. The relatively high quantum yields make MOFs 1–3 promising candidates for energy-transfer and light-harvesting applications.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, as another critical factor that determines the efficiency of light-harvesting and energy-transfer systems, the absolute fluorescence quantum yield (Φfl) of the MOFs were also investigated. The Φfl of the MOFs 1-3 is determined to be 37.1, 41.7, and 47.6%, respectively, which is slightly lower than that of the tppe ligand (57.2%). The intense solid-state emission of MOFs 1-3 should be attributed to the AIE effect originated from of the rigidification of tppe ligand in the frameworks. The relatively high quantum yields make MOFs 1-3 promising candidates for energy-transfer and light-harvesting applications.

elements.content: On the basis of the previous mentioned results, the MOF-3 was selected as a typical complex for further investigation on light-harvesting performance for its highest quantum yield, largest accessible pore volume among the three MOFs, and its relatively stable framework structure. On the other hand, rhodamine 6G (Rho6G), which is a xanthene derivative used as a gain medium in dye lasers, was selected as a model acceptor for its strong absorption in the visible region and a very high fluorescence quantum yield.
elements.clean_text:
Light-Harvesting Performances Investigations

On the basis of the previous mentioned results, the MOF-3 was selected as a typical complex for further investigation on light-harvesting performance for its highest quantum yield, largest accessible pore volume among the three MOFs, and its relatively stable framework structure. On the other hand, rhodamine 6G (Rho6G), which is a xanthene derivative used as a gain medium in dye lasers, was selected as a model acceptor for its strong absorption in the visible region and a very high fluorescence quantum yield.

elements.content: As revealed in , solid-state MOF-3 emits blue luminescence centered at 499 nm (solid blue curve) upon excitation at 370 nm (peak of the dotted blue excitation curve), with a quantum yield of about 47.6% at 25 °C. On the other hand, Rho6G in DMF (2 × 10–5 mol L–1) emits at 566 nm (solid pink curve) and its excitation profile showed a main peak at 509 nm (dotted pink curve). In contrast, Rho6G is weakly emissive upon excitation at 370 nm (fluorescence intensity = 185) (Figure S18, dotted orange curve). The emission–absorption spectral overlap of MOF-3 with Rho6G is shown as dark green shaded areas. The good spectral overlaps suggest that such Rho6G@MOF-3 could behave as an efficient fluorescence resonance energy-transfer system (). Then, the MOF-3 was loaded with different content of Rho6G, named as Rho6G@MOF-3, with an in situ method, during the synthesis process for systematic investigations (see the Supporting Information for details). The Rho6G@MOF-3 maintains their framework structure, as revealed by the similar PXRD patterns (Figure S16).
elements.clean_text: As revealed in , solid-state MOF-3 emits blue luminescence centered at 499 nm (solid blue curve) upon excitation at 370 nm (peak of the dotted blue excitation curve), with a quantum yield of about 47.6% at 25 °C. On the other hand, Rho6G in DMF (2 × 10-5 mol L-1) emits at 566 nm (solid pink curve) and its excitation profile showed a main peak at 509 nm (dotted pink curve). In contrast, Rho6G is weakly emissive upon excitation at 370 nm (fluorescence intensity = 185) (Figure S18, dotted orange curve). The emission-absorption spectral overlap of MOF-3 with Rho6G is shown as dark green shaded areas. The good spectral overlaps suggest that such Rho6G@MOF-3 could behave as an efficient fluorescence resonance energy-transfer system (). Then, the MOF-3 was loaded with different content of Rho6G, named as Rho6G@MOF-3, with an in situ method, during the synthesis process for systematic investigations (see the Supporting Information for details). The Rho6G@MOF-3 maintains their framework structure, as revealed by the similar PXRD patterns (Figure S16).

elements.content: Fluorescence excitation (dotted) and emission (solid) spectra of solid-state MOF-3 (dotted blue profile monitored at 499 nm, solid blue curve upon excitation at 370 nm) and Rho6G (dotted pink profile monitored at 566 nm, solid pink curve upon excitation at 509 nm, in DMF solvent). The green part indicates the overlap of MOF-3 emission and Rho6G excitation spectra.
elements.clean_text: 5  Fluorescence excitation (dotted) and emission (solid) spectra of solid-state MOF-3 (dotted blue profile monitored at 499 nm, solid blue curve upon excitation at 370 nm) and Rho6G (dotted pink profile monitored at 566 nm, solid pink curve upon excitation at 509 nm, in DMF solvent). The green part indicates the overlap of MOF-3 emission and Rho6G excitation spectra.

elements.content: As shown in a, the emission of the Rho6G@MOF-3 is highly dependent on the concentration of Rho6G (0.01–0.2 wt %). The Commission Internationale deL’Eclairage coordinates diagram of the Rho6G@MOF-3 with different concentrations (Figure S17) clearly exhibits the evolution of emissions. As the content of Rho6G increased, the emission color changed from light blue to bright orange. The fluorescence spectra of Rho6G@MOF-3 samples are shown in b. The fluorescence intensity of the host (MOF-3) in Rho6G@MOF-3 decreased with increased guest Rho6G concentrations and was accompanied by increase in the Rho6G emission intensity. Obviously, the relative fluorescence intensity I Rho6G/I MOF‑3 is increasing along with Rho6G concentration (c). When the content of Rho6G reaches 0.2 wt %, the relative fluorescence intensity I Rho6G/I MOF‑3 is up to 16, which is approximately 23 times larger than that of the sample with 0.01 wt % Rho6G loading (I Rho6G/I MOF‑3 = 0.7), and the emission intensity is 30 times larger than that of pure Rho6G when excited at 370 nm (Figure S18). This result indicates that the emission energy of the MOF-3 is efficiently transferred to the guest Rho6G dye molecules.

The Commission Internationale deL'Eclairage coordinates diagram of the Rho6G@MOF-3 with different concentrations (Figure S17) clearly exhibits the evolution of emissions. As the content of Rho6G increased, the emission color changed from light blue to bright orange. The fluorescence spectra of Rho6G@MOF-3 samples are shown in b. The fluorescence intensity of the host (MOF-3) in Rho6G@MOF-3 decreased with increased guest Rho6G concentrations and was accompanied by increase in the Rho6G emission intensity. Obviously, the relative fluorescence intensity I Rho6G/I MOF-3  is increasing along with Rho6G concentration (c). When the content of Rho6G reaches 0.2 wt %, the relative fluorescence intensity I Rho6G/I MOF-3  is up to 16, which is approximately 23 times larger than that of the sample with 0.01 wt % Rho6G loading (I Rho6G/I MOF-3  = 0.7), and the emission intensity is 30 times larger than that of pure Rho6G when excited at 370 nm (Figure S18). This result indicates that the emission energy of the MOF-3 is efficiently transferred to the guest Rho6G dye molecules.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence photographs of solid samples of Rho6G@MOF-3 with different loadings of Rho6G (a = 0.01 wt %, b = 0.02 wt %, c = 0.04 wt %, d = 0.1 wt %, e = 0.12 wt %, f = 0.18 wt %, and g = 0.2 wt %), excited at 365 nm. (b) The fluorescence emission spectra for Rho6G@MOF-3 with 0.01–0.20 wt % Rho6G upon excitation at 370 nm; (c) plot of relative fluorescence intensity of Rho6G to MOF-3, upon excitation of MOF-3 framework at 370 nm; (d) the guest loading-dependent absolute fluorescence quantum yield (Φfl) of MOF-3 and Rho6G under excitation at 370 nm; (e) the guest loading-dependent energy-transfer efficiency of Rho6G@MOF-3 samples.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Fluorescence photographs of solid samples of Rho6G@MOF-3 with different loadings of Rho6G (a = 0.01 wt %, b = 0.02 wt %, c = 0.04 wt %, d = 0.1 wt %, e = 0.12 wt %, f = 0.18 wt %, and g = 0.2 wt %), excited at 365 nm. (b) The fluorescence emission spectra for Rho6G@MOF-3 with 0.01-0.20 wt % Rho6G upon excitation at 370 nm; (c) plot of relative fluorescence intensity of Rho6G to MOF-3, upon excitation of MOF-3 framework at 370 nm; (d) the guest loading-dependent absolute fluorescence quantum yield (Φfl) of MOF-3 and Rho6G under excitation at 370 nm; (e) the guest loading-dependent energy-transfer efficiency of Rho6G@MOF-3 samples.

elements.content: On the other hand, as the content of Rho6G increased, the emission peak that originated from MOF-3 framework displayed a blueshift from 503 to 465 nm, whereas the emission from Rho6G red-shifted from 562 to 590 nm (Table S3, Supporting Information). The shifted emissions might be attributed to the change of the configurations of tppe ligand and the packing of Rho6G in the channels, respectively, along with the increased guest loading.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, as the content of Rho6G increased, the emission peak that originated from MOF-3 framework displayed a blueshift from 503 to 465 nm, whereas the emission from Rho6G red-shifted from 562 to 590 nm (Table S3, Supporting Information). The shifted emissions might be attributed to the change of the configurations of tppe ligand and the packing of Rho6G in the channels, respectively, along with the increased guest loading.

elements.content: Furthermore, a quantitative study of the energy-transfer process was conducted by determining the fluorescence quantum yield (Φfl) of different emission species. As shown in d, the Φfl of Rho6G increased with its concentration from 23.6% (0.01 wt %) to 42.3% (0.20 wt %), whereas the Φfl of MOF-3 decreased from 22.6% (0.01 wt %) to 2.0% (0.20 wt %), under direct excitation at 370 nm. This finding represents solid evidence that energy transfer occurs directly from the MOF-3 framework to the Rho6G dye in the channels without a radiation-reabsorption process. Additionally, the energy-transfer efficiency (ηET) estimated from the quenching rate of MOF-3 emission (=1 – Φfl(c)/Φfl(0), where c is Rho6G concentration) reaches 96% (e). The relatively high energy-transfer efficiency should be attributed to the structure feature of the MOF as well as the characteristics of the tppe ligand. The tppe ligands in the host MOF skeleton adopt a nearly planar configuration and serve as the “wall” of the channels, which is readily accessible by the guest Rho6G and benefits the host to guest energy-transfer process. Owing to these characteristics, this system represents one of the most efficient examples in MOF-to-guest energy-transfer systems (Table S5).
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, a quantitative study of the energy-transfer process was conducted by determining the fluorescence quantum yield (Φfl) of different emission species. As shown in d, the Φfl of Rho6G increased with its concentration from 23.6% (0.01 wt %) to 42.3% (0.20 wt %), whereas the Φfl of MOF-3 decreased from 22.6% (0.01 wt %) to 2.0% (0.20 wt %), under direct excitation at 370 nm. This finding represents solid evidence that energy transfer occurs directly from the MOF-3 framework to the Rho6G dye in the channels without a radiation-reabsorption process. Additionally, the energy-transfer efficiency (ηET) estimated from the quenching rate of MOF-3 emission (=1 - Φfl(c)/Φfl(0), where c is Rho6G concentration) reaches 96% (e). The relatively high energy-transfer efficiency should be attributed to the structure feature of the MOF as well as the characteristics of the tppe ligand. The tppe ligands in the host MOF skeleton adopt a nearly planar configuration and serve as the "wall" of the channels, which is readily accessible by the guest Rho6G and benefits the host to guest energy-transfer process. Owing to these characteristics, this system represents one of the most efficient examples in MOF-to-guest energy-transfer systems (Table S5).

elements.content: To evaluate the rate constant of energy transfer, we measured the lifetime of fluorescence at 499 nm originated from the emission of host MOF-3 network in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples. Considering the presence of two kinds of tppe ligands featuring distinct configurations in the framework of MOF-3, the decay profiles of the pristine MOF-3 and the host MOF-3 network in Rho6G@MOF-3 were fitted with a double-exponential function (a and Table S3). The fitting of the profile gives rise to two different lifetimes (τ1 and τ2) showing different weights, which might be assigned to the different ligands, respectively. This hypothesis could be supported by the similar weight of the lifetimes, which fit the equivalent amount of the ligands in distinct configurations well. For the pristine MOF-3, the τ1 and τ2 are 4.90 and 7.94 ns, respectively, which give rise to an average lifetime (τ0) of 6.63 ns (a, green profile). For the Rho6G@MOF-3 samples, both τ1 and τ2 reveal a decreasing trend (Table S6), which indicates that both the kinds of tppe ligands are involved in the energy-transfer process. These results are reasonable considering the relatively shorter distance between the neighboring tppe ligands in MOF-3 than the Förster radius of the system. As a result, with the Rho6G content increased from 0.01 to 0.2 wt % (a, red and blue curve), the average lifetime (τavg) of the host MOF-3 originated emission (503 nm) of Rho6G@MOF-3 samples showed a significant decrease from 2.92 to 1.31 ns (b, solid black circles; Table S3). On the basis of these results, the rate constant of energy transfer (k ENT) from the host MOF-3 skeleton to guest Rho6G, as calculated using the equation k ENT = τDA –1 – τ0 –1, increased from 0.19 × 109 to 6.11 × 109 s–1 (Table S3). Considering the relatively longer τ2 than τ1, the significantly increased k ENT should be mainly attributed to the varied τ1 along with the increased guest loading. These results suggest that the rate constant of energy transfer of the two kinds of tppe sites are different, which might be attributed to their different configurations that could affect the accessibility of guest molecules for the energy-transfer process. From b, it is clearly shown (solid red circles) that the k ENT values are highly dependent on the content of Rho6G in the Rho6G@MOF-3.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the rate constant of energy transfer, we measured the lifetime of fluorescence at 499 nm originated from the emission of host MOF-3 network in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples. Considering the presence of two kinds of tppe ligands featuring distinct configurations in the framework of MOF-3, the decay profiles of the pristine MOF-3 and the host MOF-3 network in Rho6G@MOF-3 were fitted with a double-exponential function (a and Table S3). The fitting of the profile gives rise to two different lifetimes (τ1 and τ2) showing different weights, which might be assigned to the different ligands, respectively. This hypothesis could be supported by the similar weight of the lifetimes, which fit the equivalent amount of the ligands in distinct configurations well. For the pristine MOF-3, the τ1 and τ2 are 4.90 and 7.94 ns, respectively, which give rise to an average lifetime (τ0) of 6.63 ns (a, green profile). For the Rho6G@MOF-3 samples, both τ1 and τ2 reveal a decreasing trend (Table S6), which indicates that both the kinds of tppe ligands are involved in the energy-transfer process. These results are reasonable considering the relatively shorter distance between the neighboring tppe ligands in MOF-3 than the Förster radius of the system. As a result, with the Rho6G content increased from 0.01 to 0.2 wt % (a, red and blue curve), the average lifetime (τavg) of the host MOF-3 originated emission (503 nm) of Rho6G@MOF-3 samples showed a significant decrease from 2.92 to 1.31 ns (b, solid black circles; Table S3). On the basis of these results, the rate constant of energy transfer (k ENT) from the host MOF-3 skeleton to guest Rho6G, as calculated using the equation k ENT = τDA -1 - τ0 -1, increased from 0.19 × 109 to 6.11 × 109 s-1 (Table S3). Considering the relatively longer τ2 than τ1, the significantly increased k ENT should be mainly attributed to the varied τ1 along with the increased guest loading. These results suggest that the rate constant of energy transfer of the two kinds of tppe sites are different, which might be attributed to their different configurations that could affect the accessibility of guest molecules for the energy-transfer process. From b, it is clearly shown (solid red circles) that the k ENT values are highly dependent on the content of Rho6G in the Rho6G@MOF-3.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence decay profiles of pure MOF-3 (green curve) monitored at 499 nm and the host (MOF-3) in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples (a: 0.01 wt % Rho6G, red curve monitored at 503 nm and g: 0.2 wt % Rho6G, blue curve monitored at 465 nm), the solid lines represent the best-fit using a global multiexponential function; (b) the host (MOF-3) framework fluorescence lifetime (filled black circles) and rate constant of energy transfer (filled red circles) of the energy-transfer process in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples (a–g).
elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Fluorescence decay profiles of pure MOF-3 (green curve) monitored at 499 nm and the host (MOF-3) in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples (a: 0.01 wt % Rho6G, red curve monitored at 503 nm and g: 0.2 wt % Rho6G, blue curve monitored at 465 nm), the solid lines represent the best-fit using a global multiexponential function; (b) the host (MOF-3) framework fluorescence lifetime (filled black circles) and rate constant of energy transfer (filled red circles) of the energy-transfer process in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples (a-g).

elements.content: On the other hand, we also calculated the energy-transfer efficiency on the basis of the kinetic fluorescence decay data (Table S4). These energy-transfer efficiency values obtained from the fluorescence lifetime show fair to good agreement with those obtained from the steady-state fluorescence quantum yields. All of these results suggest that the light-harvesting and energy-transformation performances of the system could be readily tuned through the modulation of guest acceptor content in this system.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, we also calculated the energy-transfer efficiency on the basis of the kinetic fluorescence decay data (Table S4). These energy-transfer efficiency values obtained from the fluorescence lifetime show fair to good agreement with those obtained from the steady-state fluorescence quantum yields. All of these results suggest that the light-harvesting and energy-transformation performances of the system could be readily tuned through the modulation of guest acceptor content in this system.

elements.content: In summary, three structurally modulated and highly luminescent 3D MOF frameworks were successfully designed and synthesized with a TPE-based ligand. The crystal structure reveals that MOF-1 is a 2-fold self-interpenetrated 3D framework, whereas MOFs 2–3 are both in pillar-layer structures with different sizes of the 1D channel. All of the MOFs show strong blue luminescence in the solid-state originating from the AIE active tppe ligand, where the vibrations and rotations of phenyl rings are restricted. The fluorescence quantum yield and light-harvesting studies  indicate that MOF-3 could be an ideal platform for  highly efficient energy transfer and delivery, with an efficiency (ηET) up to 96%. This work provides a useful insight into the reasonable design and construction of an energy transducer using luminescent MOF skeletons based on AIE active chromophores.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, three structurally modulated and highly luminescent 3D MOF frameworks were successfully designed and synthesized with a TPE-based ligand. The crystal structure reveals that MOF-1 is a 2-fold self-interpenetrated 3D framework, whereas MOFs 2-3 are both in pillar-layer structures with different sizes of the 1D channel. All of the MOFs show strong blue luminescence in the solid-state originating from the AIE active tppe ligand, where the vibrations and rotations of phenyl rings are restricted. The fluorescence quantum yield and light-harvesting studies  indicate that MOF-3 could be an ideal platform for  highly efficient energy transfer and delivery, with an efficiency (ηET) up to 96%. This work provides a useful insight into the reasonable design and construction of an energy transducer using luminescent MOF skeletons based on AIE active chromophores.

cln_elements.content:
On the basis of the considerations mentioned above, we have made much effort in this field. By utilizing 1,1,2,2-tetrakis­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­ethene (tppe), a typical TPE-based ligand that exhibits high fluorescent quantum yield, as the building block of MOFs, an unprecedented donor–acceptor system could be achieved with the energy-accepting counterparts in the confined pore structure (). Herein, we reported the targeted construction of light-harvesting MOFs based on tppe ligand. Through the coordination assembly of tppe with Zn2+/Cd2+ ions and different carboxylate building blocks, three MOFs featuring distinct porous frameworks were obtained, namely [Zn3(tppe)1.5(mdc)3]·10DMF (MOF-1), [Cd4(tppe)2(1,4-ndc)4]·8DMF (MOF-2), and [Cd2(tppe)­(2,6-ndc)2]·12DMF (MOF-3), (m-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2mdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2ndc), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc), and N′,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)) (). The resulting MOFs revealed broad tppe-based emissions (ca. 425 to 650 nm) and relatively high fluorescence quantum yield (max Φfl = 47.6%), which makes them promising candidates for light-harvesting. Furthermore, the host–guest energy-transfer properties of MOF-3, which presented the highest porosity and quantum yield among the three MOFs, were investigated in detail with rhodamine 6G (Rho6G) as the acceptor and a remarkable energy-transfer efficiency (up to 96%) was achieved. All of these results suggest that the tppe-based MOFs could be promising light-harvesting materials.

In addition to the crystal structure characterization, the phase purity of the bulk sample and stability of the MOFs were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), respectively. The PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized samples closely match those simulated from single-crystal structures, indicating the high phase purity of the bulk samples (Figure S11). On the other hand, the TGA profiles of the as-synthesized samples (Figure S12) display two continuous weight losses of 31.3% (calcd 30.7%) from 25 to 182 °C for MOF-1, three continuous weight losses of 17.8% (calcd 18.3%) from 77 to 310 °C for MOF-2, and 40.4% (calcd 38.9%) weight losses from 25 to 222 °C for MOF-3. All of these weight losses correspond to the evaporation of DMF molecules within the frameworks upon heating. Further increasing the temperature induced the collapse of these frameworks at 327, 307, and 340 °C, respectively. All of these results suggest the remarkable stability of these MOFs, which could be promising for the further investigation of their emission properties.

Porosity Characterization of MOFs <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold>

The porosity of MOFs 1–3 was analyzed by N2 adsorption isotherms obtained at 77 K. Prior to adsorption analysis, the crystals were activated at 130 °C under vacuum to remove the guest molecules in channels. As shown in , the isotherms of MOF-3 exhibit type I characteristics, which indicates the microporous nature of MOF-3. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller and Langmuir surface areas of MOF-3 were calculated to be 560 and 692 m2 g–1, respectively. In contrast, MOF-1 and MOF-2 exhibit no obvious N2 uptake. This phenomenon indicates MOF-3 is a much better candidate for loading guest molecule for energy-transfer and light-harvesting applications.
cln_elements.clean_text:
On the basis of the considerations mentioned above, we have made much effort in this field. By utilizing 1,1,2,2-tetrakis(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)ethene (tppe), a typical TPE-based ligand that exhibits high fluorescent quantum yield, as the building block of MOFs, an unprecedented donor-acceptor system could be achieved with the energy-accepting counterparts in the confined pore structure (). Herein, we reported the targeted construction of light-harvesting MOFs based on tppe ligand. Through the coordination assembly of tppe with Zn2+/Cd2+ ions and different carboxylate building blocks, three MOFs featuring distinct porous frameworks were obtained, namely [Zn3(tppe)1.5(mdc)3]⋅10DMF (MOF-1), [Cd4(tppe)2(1,4-ndc)4]⋅8DMF (MOF-2), and [Cd2(tppe)(2,6-ndc)2]⋅12DMF (MOF-3), (m-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2mdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2ndc), 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (2,6-H2ndc), and N',N-dimethylformamide (DMF)) (). The resulting MOFs revealed broad tppe-based emissions (ca. 425 to 650 nm) and relatively high fluorescence quantum yield (max Φfl = 47.6%), which makes them promising candidates for light-harvesting. Furthermore, the host-guest energy-transfer properties of MOF-3, which presented the highest porosity and quantum yield among the three MOFs, were investigated in detail with rhodamine 6G (Rho6G) as the acceptor and a remarkable energy-transfer efficiency (up to 96%) was achieved. All of these results suggest that the tppe-based MOFs could be promising light-harvesting materials.

In addition to the crystal structure characterization, the phase purity of the bulk sample and stability of the MOFs were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), respectively. The PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized samples closely match those simulated from single-crystal structures, indicating the high phase purity of the bulk samples (Figure S11). On the other hand, the TGA profiles of the as-synthesized samples (Figure S12) display two continuous weight losses of 31.3% (calcd 30.7%) from 25 to 182 °C for MOF-1, three continuous weight losses of 17.8% (calcd 18.3%) from 77 to 310 °C for MOF-2, and 40.4% (calcd 38.9%) weight losses from 25 to 222 °C for MOF-3. All of these weight losses correspond to the evaporation of DMF molecules within the frameworks upon heating. Further increasing the temperature induced the collapse of these frameworks at 327, 307, and 340 °C, respectively. All of these results suggest the remarkable stability of these MOFs, which could be promising for the further investigation of their emission properties.

Porosity Characterization of MOFs 1-3 

The porosity of MOFs 1-3 was analyzed by N2 adsorption isotherms obtained at 77 K. Prior to adsorption analysis, the crystals were activated at 130 °C under vacuum to remove the guest molecules in channels. As shown in , the isotherms of MOF-3 exhibit type I characteristics, which indicates the microporous nature of MOF-3. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller and Langmuir surface areas of MOF-3 were calculated to be 560 and 692 m2 g-1, respectively. In contrast, MOF-1 and MOF-2 exhibit no obvious N2 uptake. This phenomenon indicates MOF-3 is a much better candidate for loading guest molecule for energy-transfer and light-harvesting applications.

cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Fluorescence photographs of solid samples of Rho6G@MOF-3 with different loadings of Rho6G (a = 0.01 wt %, b = 0.02 wt %, c = 0.04 wt %, d = 0.1 wt %, e = 0.12 wt %, f = 0.18 wt %, and g = 0.2 wt %), excited at 365 nm. (b) The fluorescence emission spectra for Rho6G@MOF-3 with 0.01-0.20 wt % Rho6G upon excitation at 370 nm; (c) plot of relative fluorescence intensity of Rho6G to MOF-3, upon excitation of MOF-3 framework at 370 nm; (d) the guest loading-dependent absolute fluorescence quantum yield (Φfl) of MOF-3 and Rho6G under excitation at 370 nm; (e) the guest loading-dependent energy-transfer efficiency of Rho6G@MOF-3 samples.

cln_elements.content: (a) Fluorescence decay profiles of pure MOF-3 (green curve) monitored at 499 nm and the host (MOF-3) in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples (a: 0.01 wt % Rho6G, red curve monitored at 503 nm and g: 0.2 wt % Rho6G, blue curve monitored at 465 nm), the solid lines represent the best-fit using a global multiexponential function; (b) the host (MOF-3) framework fluorescence lifetime (filled black circles) and rate constant of energy transfer (filled red circles) of the energy-transfer process in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples (a–g).
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Fluorescence decay profiles of pure MOF-3 (green curve) monitored at 499 nm and the host (MOF-3) in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples (a: 0.01 wt % Rho6G, red curve monitored at 503 nm and g: 0.2 wt % Rho6G, blue curve monitored at 465 nm), the solid lines represent the best-fit using a global multiexponential function; (b) the host (MOF-3) framework fluorescence lifetime (filled black circles) and rate constant of energy transfer (filled red circles) of the energy-transfer process in Rho6G@MOF-3 samples (a-g).

metadata.title:
Targeted
Construction of Light-Harvesting Metal–Organic Frameworks Featuring
Efficient Host–Guest Energy Transfer
